PublisherName.String: MRC Lifecourse Epidemiology Unit, University of Southampton

Copyright.String: Copyright MRC Lifecourse Epidemiology Unit, University of Southampton. All rights reserved.

Abstract.Content: The Southampton Women's Survey (SWS) is the only birth cohort study in Europe in which the mothers were recruited before conception of the child. It is run by the MRC Lifecourse Epidemiology Unit at the University of Southampton. The aim is the assess and influence of maternal dietary, lifestyle, intrauterine, genetic and epigenetic factors on the children's health and development, and on the health of the mothers themselves. Between 1998 and 2002 the Survey team interviewed 12,583 Southampton women aged 20 to 34 years. Those who became pregnant after interview were invited to take part in the pregnancy phase of the survey. Women received ultrasound scans at 11, 29 and 34 weeks of pregnancy, and their babies were measured soon after birth, and their babies were measured soon after birth. There were 3,158 babies born in the study between 1998 and 2007. The survey has also followed up these children with home visits at six months, one year, two and three years. Samples of the cohort are being followed up subsequently with over 1,000 children seen at 4 years of age, more than 2,000 at ages 6-7 years, and more than 1,000 at 8-9 years. Most recently, the children are being followed up at 11-13 years. Study website: https://www.mrc.soton.ac.uk/sws/

PublisherName.String: MRC Lifecourse Epidemiology Unit, University of Southampton

Abstract.Content: The target population was all women living in Southampton and neighbouring areas aged 20-34 years and not pregnant at the time of recruitment. Women were recruited through their GPs, as well as at local events in Southampton. Research nurses visited the women in their homes and conducted an interview, obtained anthropometry measurements and mouth wash samples for genetic analysis. Subsequently, those who were willing provided a blood sample either at their GP surgery or at home. Study website: https://www.mrc.soton.ac.uk/sws/

Description.Content: All participants were recruited when they were resident in the city of Southampton and neighbouring areas.
Face-to-face paper and pencil interviewing.
Assessment of physical properties of living being, objects, materials, or natural phenomena. This includes medical and geographic data.
Face-to-face paper and pencil interviewing.
Assessment of physical properties of living being, objects, materials, or natural phenomena. This includes medical and geographic data.

PublisherName.String: MRC Lifecourse Epidemiology Unit, University of Southampton

Abstract.Content: Women who took part in the initial interview for the SWS were asked for their consent for their GP to inform the study if they became pregnant, and were also asked to inform the study themselves. Some 3158 women took part in the pregnancy component of the study and delivered a live born singleton baby. During pregnancy, data were collected at 11, 19 and 34 weeks’ gestation, ultrasound scanning was conducted at each visit, and blood samples were collected. Study website: https://www.mrc.soton.ac.uk/sws/

Description.Content: All participants were from Southampton and neighbouring areas.
Face-to-face paper and pencil interviewing.

PublisherName.String: MRC Lifecourse Epidemiology Unit, University of Southampton

Abstract.Content: Anthropometric data were collected from the babies within 4 days of birth. Information about the pregnancy and labour was abstracted from the maternal medical notes. Study website: https://www.mrc.soton.ac.uk/sws/

Description.Content: All participants were born and remain resident in the county of Hertfordshire.
Face-to-face paper and pencil interviewing.
Assessment of physical properties of living being, objects, materials, or natural phenomena. This includes medical and geographic data.
Collecting and assembling data from multiple, often heterogeneous sources that have one or more reference points in common, and at least one of the sources was originally produced for other purposes.

PublisherName.String: MRC Lifecourse Epidemiology Unit, University of Southampton

Abstract.Content: Participants were visited at home by a trained research nurse. Information collected included diet, illnesses, allergies and anthropometry. Study website: https://www.mrc.soton.ac.uk/sws/
